texts.shortText: Fairly small, soft-bodied, cylindrical and dark olive-green to jet-black. Dorsally the tube feet are mostly confined to distinct bands, although a few are also scattered between these bands. Ventrally the tube feet are confined to distinct bands, each with no more than four rows. There are 10 equal-sized dendritic tentacles. Often insinuated into crevices in the rocks or between other sedentary organisms. Juveniles mainly under rocks, but adults in the open.
Body length typically about 60 mm, excluding tentacles.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to southern Mozambique.
Usually found singly or on small groups, attached in crevices or under boulders on rocky shores. Juveniles often under rocks, but adults usually exposed in the open.

Tentacles held up into the water column to intercept floating particles in the plankton. Each tentacle is then inserted in turn into the mouth to be licked clean and recoated in sticky mucous before being held aloft again.

Not studied in this species, but in most cucumbers sexes are separate and sperm and eggs released via broadcast spawning and develop into planktonic larvae that are dispersed by ocean currents before settling onto suitable substrata.

Easily confused in the field with the very similar Stephenson’s sea cucumber Roweia stephensoni, which is similar in both colour and habits. However, when closely examined that species has the tube feet on the dorsal surface not grouped into distinct bands and there are 6 rows of tube in each of the ventral bands, rather than 4.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 240).

Thandar, AS (1991). The Cucumariid holothurians of southern Africa with the erection of a new genus. South African Journal of Zoology, 26(3): 115 – 139.

Thandar, AS (2022). A Taxonomic Monograph of the Sea Cucumbers of Southern Africa (Echinodermata: Holothuriodea). Suricata 9. South African National Biodiversity Institute, Pretoria. (p. 117).
